project.objective: The immune system is remodeled with age, going through a series of changes known as “immunosenescence’, including the involution of primary lymphoid organs, the contraction of the immune repertoire, a progressive lineage skewing towards the myeloid lineage and a low-grade pro-inflammatory status. A consequence of immunosenescence impacting the morbidity and mortality of infectious diseases is a dramatically reduced vaccine response in the elderly. Thus, reducing the burden of immunosenescence has the potential to impact the effectiveness of vaccine response. An established hallmark and driver of age-associated functional decline is telomere dysfunction. Dysfunctional telomeres are actively transcribed to generate telomeric non-coding RNAs (tncRNA) which are essential to recruit DNA Damage Response (DDR) factors at damaged telomeres, thus fueling DDR and causing cellular senescence initiation and maintenance. Sequence-specific telomeric antisense oligonucleotides (tASOs) target these tncRNAs and effectively inhibit DDR activation, ameliorating age-related phenotypes in mouse models. The telomerase-deficient (Terc-/-) mouse model, causes telomere shortening and dysfunction, recapitulating features of immunosenescence: immune system reactivity reduction, decreased long term renewal of hematopoietic stem cells and lymphocytes numbers, increased neutrophil count. tASOs treatment has beneficial long-term effect in this model, by decreasing immunosenescence and counteracting inflammation. We now plan to test the efficacy of tASOs treatment on ‘rejuvenating’ the immune system of aged wild type mice, a ‘physiological’ setting for aging. The final goal will be to assess if tASOs impact on vaccine response in both models: young Terc-/- mice and aged WT mice. In summary, we plan to determine the efficacy of tASOs to improve immune responses, including vaccines, in the elderly.

result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: DATA MANAGEMENT PLAN1. Data SummaryTELOVACCINE is an original research proposal aimed at finding a new strategy to improve vaccine response by fighting immunosenescence through telomeric DNA damage response inhibition. Original data collection will represent the main instrument for the advancement of the project and to achieve its milestones through extensive data analysis. The data will be generated by the equipment used in the project: these are mainly composed by commercially available machinery, run by licensed software. 2.FAIR Data•Making data findableRaw data will be generated by the different equipment and stored in the dedicated folder on the institutional storage server to ensure permanent storage of data. To keep track of the research plan, a personal electronic lab-book will be provided at the host institute. Some raw data will be generated by the software running the specific equipment and, in the case of commercial systems run by licensed software, only the dedicated software can read this type of data. •Making data openly accessibleAll the data analysed and included in future publication will be made accessible by third parts, including the raw data included in pre-print publications. All the remaining data (not part of scientific publication in peer-reviewed journals), will be stored at the home institute (IFOM-ETS) and made available upon official request. All the data generated by TELOVACCINE will be accessible by the most common software packages (e.g. Microsoft Office) or by free-license open-access software (e.g. ImageJ). Some data analysis will be carried out on licensed software (e.g. Graphpad Prism, FlowJo); in these specific case final reports readable by Microsoft Office or open-access equivalent software will be provided. •Making data interoperableThe raw data can be of interest for other researchers or for spin off projects. Most of the data generated will take advantage of pre-determined standard operating procedures, therefore research data will be reproducible and can be used for further research or applications. All the experimental procedures will be described in the associated file on the electronic labbook at the Host Institute (IFOM-ETS) with an appropriate, standard and comprehensible vocabulary to preserve interoperability of the original data.•Increase data re-useThe data will be shared with third parties after approval of the Principle Investigator. The criteria and time period will be determined on a case-by-case basis.3. Allocation of resourcesData FAIR policy is already in place at the Host Institute, which is providing the IT infrastructures and technical support to ensure correct data handling and storage. The researcher and the supervisor will be responsible for the data management of the project. TELOVACCINE will comply with the internal policy. 4. Data SecurityThe data generated by TELOVACCINE will be stored in agreement with the internal regulation for data handling and storage at the host institute.
